title: High CPU usage when streaming Xfinity DVR recordings
content:
I know there are a number of postings and Suggestions for addressing high CPU usage with Firefox but I've tried them all to no avail. So forgive me for raising the topic again.

My problem is as follows. I have multiple recordings made on my Xfinity account. These recordings are all HD quality which is I believe 720p with Xfinity. I can play these recordings using Xfinity Stream using Firefox as my browser on my desktop PC and it works fine with the CPU usage only being about 8%.

When I try to watch the same recording on my laptop which is underpowered by comparison the video stutters, freezes and in many cases just stops altogether. The CPU is maxed out at 100% and Firefox is using most of that with the plugin-container.exe using 40% of the total. I've tried turning off hardware acceleration and it makes no difference. I believe the issue is down to the plugin-container just getting bogged down (is the container running Widevine DRM?).

I can watch stream On-Demand and LiveTV from Xfinity because there are other sources of the programs so adaptive resolution kicks in and I get a lower quality video (but still a nearly maxed out CPU). With the DVR recording there is no lower quality file available so adaptive resolution does not apply.

The same laptop is capable of streaming 1080p Netflix when at 100%. I can see the Netflix resolution using the Ctl-Shift-Alt-D while streaming a movie.

So I'm convinced that my problem is all down to lack of CPU power for browser based DRM. But why should that be? Is it just a poor implementation of DRM support? (BTW the situation is no different using Chrome or Edge which also use Widevine DRM).

So 2 specific questions:

1. Is there a way when streaming a video with Firefox of seeing what the resolution the video is actually playing at (this is assuming adaptive routing is in effect)?

2. Are there any specifications that would tell me the required minimum Intel CPU that can handle streaming HD video with DRM. Assume the network is not an issue.

Additional information. Laptop has an Intel Celeron N2815 @1.86GHz CPU. I'm running Windows 10 20H2 with all patches up to date. My network is 1Gbs download and 40Mbs upload. The laptop can achieve 200Mbs download and 40Mbs upload. I'm running the latest version of Firefox with no extensions installed.

Thanks for any insight into this issue Mike
creator: lenaghanm

Perhaps the worst part is I ALSO can't access any settings. I can press the menu, 3 bar icon in the top right corner, but when I click any of those things, nothing happens. I don't know what to do.

I don't know if firefox somehow auto updated or something and it broke or what. I was literally using it, I had like 4 or 5 active tabs open with loaded windows and it just stopped working.

Any help would be appreciated as I'd still prefer firefox and don't want to deal with getting everything switched to chrome.

Didn't see the edit post button initially but here's some more troubleshooting I've done: I ran firefox in safe mode, nothing changed. I ran CCleaner in hopes if getting rid of temporary files which could mess with stuff, nothing changed. I restarted my computer, and what do you know, nothing changed.

title: New Print dialog plus and minus
content:
There's another thread (or more) where people are shocked by the new Print dialog - and the fact that the developers say that the option to return to the old Print dialog (which is apparently the "system" dialog) will eventually be removed.

I have to say that for me the new Print dialog is not an obvious improvement over the old one, so I don't understand what is the driving force behind making the change. Maybe this change is something that makes more sense on phones and tablets, making Firefox more OS-agnostic? But I'm on a Windows 10 computer and I really like the old system better. How many people print from a phone? I think that's more of a desktop usage.

For me, inevitably, I do two things before I print a web page: (1) I preview it to make sure that the scaling doesn't truncate and omit things that might be on the right edge of the page; and (2) I ALWAYS check for pages that have no useful information, so I can select and print only the pages that are worth printing. After reading the other thread, I realize now that the new Print dialog does allow me to do these things, but it doesn't make them as convenient as before. It takes more clicks to open up the necessary dialog steps that IMHO should be front and center to begin with.

title: FR: Focus last viewed tab after closing a tab
content:
When I close a tab, by default Firefox selects the next tab on the right or the one on the left if the closed tab was the right-most tab. There is an option in about:config

browser.tabs.selectOwnerOnClose

When this option is set to True, firefox will focus the owner.

Neither of these two behaviours is particularly useful. I want Firefox to select the last vieved tab, not the parent, and not the one to the left/right. Currently I'm using add-on Select after closing current which does exactly what I want, however previous versions of Firefox could do this out of the box, and so can Chrome. I think most users would find it useful if this was the default behaviour, thanks!

title: After most recent update - I've lost my extensions/add-ons, logins, and the urls in the bookmarks.
content:
The Bookmarks are all there, but the url is missing. None of the extensions (including ones I've paid for are there)

The logins weren't there, but are now restored from a previous install.

What I have done...

1. exported bookmarks to html and checked them out there. They were broken there as well.

2. Refreshed Firefox,

3. Restarted the PC.

4. Uninstalled Firefox (and discovered that I had both X32 and X64 on my machine) - uninstalled both. 5. Reinstalled Firefox x64 (current version 86.0.1)

6. the places.sqlite files from previous restores have the same problem.

I've started to refresh the links for the toolbar which has taken me awhile. I don't want to have to do it for all my hundred's of bookmarks.

Ideally what I'd like to do is uninstall the latest update, look at the bookmarks to see if they are still stuffed, and if the extensions are there. If they are ok, then I want to back the bookmarks to html. Reinstall the update, then restore the bookmarks. (And make a list of the extension names so I can reinstall them).

My guess is either that the sqlite file has corrupted, or the update has changed the file layout for the bookmarks, etc, and it's unable to interpret the links.
